Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to:
Support the delivery of high quality clinical services for prisoners from Her Majesty's Prison Service and persons under police arrest
Maintain a high standard of security for all wards and departments of the Trust providing care to prisoners from Her Majesty's Prison Service and persons under police arrest

Ensure that the personal safety and wellbeing of all Trust staff, patients & visitors are not compromised when care is provided to prisoners from Her Majesty's Prison Service and persons under police arrest.
It is standard for the Trust to refer to prisoners as patients. However for ease of identification and clarity the term prisoner will be used throughout this document.
Introduction

This policy identifies the care and custody arrangements for prisoners from Her Majesty's Prison Service and persons under police arrest who require treatment at Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust.
Scope
This policy applies to all patients who require Trust services, the staff who work for the Trust and staff from the Police and HM Prison Service who are required to attend site with prisoners.
The Law
Section 22(2) b of the Prison Act 1952 makes specific provision for taking prisoners under escort to hospital for treatment. The effects of the provisions are:
That any prisoner requiring hospital treatment should be taken to hospital, that is, should not be allowed to make his own way there and
Be taken there in custody that is, accompanied by a Prison Officer

The Trust has a duty of care to persons under arrest or are subject to a prison order under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 section 4 and Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 regulation
Responsibilities
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the health, safety and welfare of persons on premises.
Security Management Director (SMD)
The Chief Estates & Facilities Officer is nominated as the SMD.
The SMD will ensure compliance with this policy on behalf of the Chief Executive
The SMD will ensure any prisoner or person under police arrest will receive the appropriate treatment, admission and discharge to any service within the Trust.
The SMD will provide support and guidance at executive level for matters relating to security and welfare of prisoners on site.
Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS)

5.3.1  The Trusts LSMS and who acts as Police Liaison will be informed of prisoner attendance or police attendance with prisoners on site for information as appropriate. It is the responsibility for the LSMS to ensure that:

a risk assessment should be in place as directed by Prison/ Police Officers for the duration of any inpatient stay should the prisoner be deemed high risk determined through notification by Prison/ Police Officers.
updates to the SMD on prisoner movement within the Trust is provided if required.
any incidents involving prisoners and persons in custody on premises are investigated, and outcomes regularly reviewed with Police/ Prison service liaison.
good communication between the Trust and the Police/ Prison service as appropriate
HMP and Essex Police are liaised with on professional matters associated with the conduct of officers as appropriate
Security & Portering Manager

5.4.1  The Security and Portering Manager is responsible for ensuring that the security team are updated with relevant information around prisoner movement within the Trust. The Security and Portering Manager will attend bed meetings as appropriate when prisoners are admitted as inpatients. The Security and Portering Manager is also responsible for ensuring that:
security and portering staff are debriefed with information relevant to persons under arrest on site and associated risks etc.
incidents associated with prisoners are reported and investigated
prisoner attendance and events are reported to the LSMS
Security/ Porters

Security porters will be notified by the Clinical Operations Manager that a prisoner or person under arrest is on site. If the Clinical Operations Team is unavailable the Police or Prison Service will notify the Security Supervisors directly.
Any events of HM Prison service or Police failing to notify the Trust of arrival with a prisoner must be notified to the Security and Portering Manager and LSMS.
In cases of serious incidents or serious security breaches the LSMS and SMD should be notified as soon as possible (by telephone) to conduct a full investigation.
Security Porters may also be required to support officers on site for transport or department/ hospital lockdown purposes.
Medical Staff
5.6.1  The Medical Ethics Department of the British Medical Association has produced guidance for Doctors providing care and treatment to those detained, summarised as:
Detained prisoners must have access to the same standards of care as the wider community. This includes respect for the patient's dignity and privacy
Wherever possible, without compromising the quality of care, treatment should be provided within the prison. Conditions of privacy must be available

There should be a presumption that prisoners will be examined and treated without restraints and without Prison Officers/ Police Officers present, unless there is a risk of escape or the prisoner represents a threat to him or herself, the Health Team or others

Discussions should take place between the Health Team and the Prison/ Police Officers to assess the level of risk in each particular case. If, after discussion, the level of risk is low, the Doctor in charge should request removal of restraints

In an emergency situation, treatment must be provided and a Clinician can demand the removal of restraints irrespective of the perceived level of risk. Clinicians can ask only about the patient's medical condition and not ask for any information surrounding their circumstances to be in a hospital setting

No photographs are allowed to be taken on the patient unless specifically required and documented as to why they are required. Photographs can only be taken through official photography means and not on mobile telephones
Nursing Staff
Nursing staff are responsible for providing treatment to patients and maintaining their privacy, dignity and confidentiality.

Should a prisoner become violent to a point where the HM Prison Service Staff cannot safely control the situation or where a prisoner escapes (or an attempt is made to escape), Trust staff will be requested to contact the Police on (9)999.
The Sister/Nurse in charge of the ward/unit must make daily communication with the prison officers/ police officers regarding the prisoner's current medical condition.

At no point are nursing staff permitted to ask the nature of the persons arrest/ incarceration or request further information than that otherwise provided by the staff, unless specifically needed for the medical condition. If further information is required the Senior Nurse or Clinician must discuss with the Police/ Prison service.
Nursing staff are not permitted to take photographs of patients without authorisation for clinical purposes only.
Clinical Operations Managers/ Bed Management

Essex Police and HM Prison Service have been requested to phone through in advance when en-route to the hospital with a patient, this will allow ample time to try and allocate an appropriate ward/ room for the patient to go to should inpatient treatment be required. Other police forces may not phone ahead to
the clinical operations managers but as soon as senior staff are aware they should contact the clinical operations managers by phone or bleep.
The clinical operations Team will be notified should a prisoner require an inpatient bed by the Clinician/ Nurse in charge of the prisoners care

Should a call be received that a person under arrest by Essex Police or a Prisoner from HM Prison Service is en-route to the hospital, the Clinical Operations Manager must notify Security Supervisor on duty immediately for information and support as appropriate

It is the duty of the bed manager to ensure that an appropriate location is found for the patient and the area is agreed with the prison/ police officers prior to allocating the pace to the prisoner, the prisoner must remain the safest location until it is suitable to transfer them
Prisoners should be provided with a side room, to minimise interaction with other patients, and to provide privacy to them and the Officers present
Prisoner requirements must be assessed by the Clinical Operations Manager on a case by case basis with support from the LSMS, Security Portering Supervisor and SMD
Details should be provided to the on call manager, Executive on Call and to the LSMS when a bed has been allocated to a prisoner
HM Prison Service
HMP staff must notify hospital Clinical Operations Team on the day when a prisoner is being escorted to hospital for either outpatient appointment or in- patient episode

If a prisoner is being brought to the hospital for an emergency reason a phone call should be made to the Clinical Operations Team en-route. The call is to be made via switchboard on 01245 443673 ext:  The Clinical Operations Team will then request for assistance from the Security team on site as appropriate
Should there be no answer redial for the switchboard on 01245 443673 and request to speak with a Security Supervisor for assistance
HMP staff are to remain with the prisoner at all times during outpatient or inpatient stay

HMP staff must comply with Trust infection prevention and control hand washing and hygiene protocols and be willing to participate in training with the infection prevention and control team where required
HMP staff must not use mobile phones within hospital buildings for any purpose other than work. Under no circumstances are photographs of any nature to be taken on mobile phones
HMP staff are to liaise with Senior Nurse or Clinician in the department to discuss treatment arrangements for the prisoner

HMP staff may be required to provide Trust staff with a copy of a risk assessment for pre arranged inpatient stays to inform the Trust of appropriate risk management action being taken to ensure the safety of the prisoner, Trust staff and other patients
Unless there are overriding security reasons, HMP staff will not provide any circumstantial or personal details of the prisoner to Trust staff
Under no circumstances will HMP staff touch, or interfere with clinical equipment in any way
HMP staff are expected to adhere to the Trust's Smoke Free Policy at all times.
Essex Police
Police staff must notify hospital security on the day when a person under arrest is being escorted to hospital for either outpatient or in-patient appointments

If a person under arrest is being brought to the hospital for an emergency reason a phone call should be made to the Clinical Operations Team en- route. The call is to be made via switchboard on 01245 362000ext: 4666. The Clinical Operations Team will then request for assistance from the Security team on site as appropriate
Should there be no answer redial for the switchboard on 01245 362000 and request to speak with a Security Supervisor for assistance
Police staff are to remain with the person under arrest at all times during outpatient or inpatient stay

Police staff must comply with Trust infection prevention and control hand washing and hygiene protocols and be willing to participate in training with the infection prevention and control team where required
Police staff must not use mobile phones within hospital buildings for any purpose other than work. Under no circumstances are photographs of any nature to be taken on mobile phones
Police staff are to liaise with Senior Nurse or Clinician in the department to discuss treatment arrangements for the person under arrest

Police staff may be required to provide Trust staff with a copy of a risk assessment for inpatient stays to inform the Trust of appropriate risk management action being taken to ensure the safety of the prisoner, Trust staff and other patients
Unless there are overriding security reasons, Police staff will not provide any details of the prisoner to Trust staff
Under no circumstances will Police staff touch, or interfere with clinical equipment in any way
Police staff are expected to adhere to the Trust's Smoke Free Policy at all times.
HMP and Police Security Responsibilities and Accountability

5.11.1 Escorted prisoners will always attend handcuffed, including whilst the prisoner is an inpatient. An escort chain (a long chain attached to the prisoner's handcuffs) can be utilised to support privacy and can be used following a risk assessment by the HM Prison Service Staff.

5.11.2 The use of handcuffs is to protect the public, patients and staff and is undertaken following a considered risk assessment. If it is not possible for HM Prison Service staff / Police to remove handcuffs at the request of Trust staff, outside of theatres, maternity care or during a life threatening emergency as identified by clinical staff. Trust staff should be made aware that handcuff cannot be removed and the reasons for this. If agreement cannot be reached, the Chief Executive/ Executive on-call/ Security Management Director (SMD) should discuss the case with the police present or Governor of the prison.
5.11.3 The responsibility for the security and safety of the prisoner from a HM Prison rests at all times with the HM Prison Service Staff.
5.11.4 The responsibility for the security and safety of the person under arrest by the Police rests at all times with the Police Force presently involved in managing the prisoner.
5.11.5 Clinical responsibility remains with the clinicians and the Trust.

5.11.6 HM Prison Service Staff/ Police Staff will undertake an on the spot assessment of consultation/treatment rooms, waiting rooms and inpatient areas to assess risks. Trust staff should advise the staff of any known issues which may affect security during the prisoners visit.

5.11.7 Any suspicious circumstances noted by Trust Security staff (or reported to Trust Security staff) detected though patrol observation or CCTV surveillance, which may be connected with the prisoner or their visit, must be immediately reported to the HM Prison Service Staff and investigated accordingly. If appropriate the Police may also be called by Trust Security Staff to assist with any perceived or actual compromise of site security.

5.11.8 All details of prisoner visits to Trust premises and any subsequent action taken by Security Staff should be recorded by the Trust. If appropriate a standard Trust Incident report may also be completed detailing any security action that has been undertaken.

5.11.9 The level of security necessary in all cases must be kept under review to take into account, the prisoner's developing medical condition, the physical surroundings in which the prisoner is located and any emerging intelligence.
All Staff

5.12.1 At no point are staff permitted to ask the nature of the persons arrest/ incarceration or request further information than that otherwise provided by the staff, unless specifically needed for the medical condition. If further information is required the Senior Nurse or Clinician must discuss with the Police/ Prison service.
5.12.2 All staff are not permitted to take photographs of patients without authorisation for clinical purposes only.

5.12.3 All staff members who are likely to come into contact with prisoners and persons under arrest are responsible for making themselves aware of the content of this policy. The Trust will ensure this policy is made available to staff.
Use of Restraints

Restraints must be attached between the prisoner and an Escorting Officer. They MUST NOT be used to attach prisoners to furniture or any other fixtures or fittings. The Prison Officers / Police escorting a patient are under instruction to maintain the security deemed necessary by the Governor following the Risk Assessment Procedure.

If a Doctor, Nurse or Health Care Professional seeks the removal of restraints because of an immediate risk to the health of the prisoner, or if the prisoner is in pain or discomfort, or because restraints are impeding essential treatment, they must normally be removed. Escorting staff must immediately notify their Senior Person in charge/ Governor in case additional security arrangements need to be made.

Similarly, if a Doctor or Senior Health Care Professional seeks the removal of restraints where immediate treatment is not required - because they are impending examination or treatment, the restraints should be removed unless a risk of escape remains, or if the Escort Staff are in doubt they must seek advice from the prison/ Police Inspector.

Whenever staff of any grade feel that handcuffs should be removed, including life threatening emergencies, this must be immediately communicated to the Duty Consultant and recorded in the medical notes. If for some reason the Duty Consultant is not immediately available to endorse the instruction, the Doctor or Senior Nurse can request the removal of handcuffs if the clinical situation is urgent and must then inform the Duty Consultant as soon as possible.
In the event of any disagreement amongst Clinical Staff over custody arrangements, the Trust's Chief Medical Officer must be contacted.
The Consultant in charge of the patient's care must ensure that liaison with the Prison Staff is at an appropriate level at all times:
At ward level to decrease stress to Ward Staff and enable them to care
For all patients equitably
To maintain confidentiality of information on the individual patient
To assist the Prison/ Police Service determine an appropriate level of bed watch
To assist the Prison Governor/ Police Inspector to be aware of any concerns over the conduct of a bed watch
Arrival on Site

On arrival at the Trust the main concern of the HM Prison Service Staff is swift entry into the relevant department. To facilitate this when attending the Trust the custody vehicle will park at the Main Reception entrance on its arrival.

If the vehicle is staying for the duration of the visit the Trust Security Staff will be contacted and arrangements made for the vehicle to be parked in an allocated location. No charge will be made by the Trust for parking.
The prisoner and the escort staff will enter the building through the Main Reception and proceed to their destination.

Any requests for the prisoner and escort staff to enter the building through an alternative entrance will be made by the Prison Security Department/ Police Inspector to the Security Department and Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS), if the LSMS is unavailable the Security Management (SMD) must be contacted prior to arrival on site.
Out-patient appointments

Where appropriate, arrangements will be made for the prisoner and the HM Prison Service Staff to be placed in a consultation room or a discrete waiting area away from the public as soon as possible following their arrival to the relevant department. This is not only to enhance security but to reduce discomfort for other patients and the public.

In order to minimise any discomfort to the general public and the prisoner and to reduce security risks, Managers are requested to give consideration to minimising the length of time prisoners are required to wait wherever possible. For example, allowing the prisoner to wait in the prison environment before attendance rather than in a department.
In the event of a hostile reaction from persons within the waiting area the HM Prison Service Staff will advise the Nurse in Charge and request relocation.

During assessment, examination or treatment of the prisoner appropriate protective clothing, i.e. lead jackets for X-ray examinations, will be provided by the Trust for the HM Prison Service Staff and where appropriate should be worn at all times. In an attempt to minimise radiation source from the HM Prison Service Staff it is advisable that they use the longest length of escort chain permissible during X- ray examinations of the prisoner which should enable the attending escort to remain behind the lead protective screen.
Prisoners attending hospital outpatients should, whenever possible:
Be given an appointment at the start of the clinic.
To avoid embarrassment to both prisoners and to other patients, not be kept in the main waiting area.
Be seen as soon as possible by a Consultant or Senior Doctor.

The clinical report following an outpatients' appointment should be sent at the earliest possible time to the Prison Medical Officer. The Prison Medical Officer should be contacted by telephone to provide a verbal update pending issue of the report.
If the prisoner requires immediate admission to hospital, the Doctor in clinic should:
Inform the admitting ward that a prisoner with escort is arriving. (the ward must then inform the site office)
Inform by telephone the Prison Medical Officer or Duty Governor.
The Escorting Officer should be informed and then contact the Duty Governor to arrange an immediate review of the Risk Assessment.
The Prison will make all reasonable efforts to ensure that prisoners are able to attend their planned hospital appointments.
Management of Did Not Attends (DNA's)

There can be 3 Did Not Attends (DNA's) before a request is returned to the Prison Healthcare Centre for re-assessment. A DNA refers to when a patient does not arrive for appointment without any prior notification.
Inpatient Care

On admission of a prisoner or person under arrest the provider hospitals, where possible, must provide a single room with a separate toilet and bathroom, to improve security and to keep disruption and discomfort of other patients and their families to a minimum.
The HM Prison Staff/Police escorting staff will also require access to a telephone in order to communicate with their colleagues/ management teams.
HM Prison Service Staff/ Police Staff should be advised by Trust staff at the earliest opportunity of the prisoner's expected length of stay.

The Senior Nurse in charge of the relevant ward will inform the HM Prison Service Staff/ Police staff if the prisoner is to be moved to an alternative ward during their stay in hospital. The HM Prison Service Staff/ Police Staff will then be responsible for informing the relevant person(s) of any such arrangement
In all cases of a prisoner attending a Hospital appointment or to receive treatment via Accident and Emergency the Hospital Security Department must be informed.
Theatres

For prisoners requiring surgery the HM Prison Service Staff/ Police staff will attend up to and during the anaesthetic induction of the patient. Once the prisoner is anaesthetised the handcuffs will be removed and the escort staff will wait outside the theatre until surgery is complete.

There have been reported instances in UK hospitals of HM Prison Service Staff/ Police staff being asked to remove their uniforms in exchange for sterile clothing. Forces Staff are not permitted to remove their uniforms because of the security risks this poses should any theft occur. Escort Staff are not required to enter theatres.
Once the Post Operative Recovery Nurse has assessed that the prisoner is emerging from the anaesthetic escort staff must be asked to return to the prisoner and will re-apply handcuffs.
Discharge Arrangements (Outpatients, Inpatients)

HMP Prison Service Staff will not be provided with verbal discharge instructions only. Instead Prison Healthcare Departments must be provided with written discharge information on the prisoner's treatment and ongoing care needs. This is to ensure that the patient's ongoing care requirements are fully met.
Written discharge information will provided to Prison Service Staff in a sealed envelope to maintain medical confidentiality
Exceptional Escort Requirements
Should any additional / exceptional escort requirements be required the LSMS and relevant Department/ Ward will be notified by the Prison Service.
Visitors

The Prison Governor/ Police Inspector, in consultation with the Trust, will determine the arrangements by which visitors are permitted to see the prisoner. Arrangements will depend on individual circumstances and the prisoner's risk assessment.
Risk Assessments

All prisoners undergo a robust and considered assessment prior to attending any external healthcare appointment. This assessment determines the level of risk the prisoner poses and the appropriate level of HM Prison service Staff required. The risk assessment is signed off by the Prison Governor prior to the escort leaving the prison. As a minimum all prisoners will be escorted by a prison escort/s.
If a person under arrest remains in hospital requiring Police to stay on bed watch at the hospital then a risk assessment will be undertaken to determine the risks identified for them to stay.

A request can be made by LSMS for details of the Prison Service Risk Assessment. Whenever the condition of the patient alters, the Risk Assessment is revised. Clinical details of relevance should be communicated to the establishments Healthcare Department on a daily basis.

The ward /department lead will complete a risk assessment for each prisoner/ person under arrest on site based on the information made available by Police or HM Prison Service. This risk assessment must be communicated and made available to the Trust security manager and LSMS.

Should the police or HM Prison Service risk assessment identify any mental health issues with the prisoner ward /department leads must communicate these to the Trusts mental health liaison staff in order that ward / departmental risk assessments include input from mental health professionals and identify appropriate actions to safeguard the prisoner.
Category of Prisoner defined by HM Prison service.
The Security categories into which a prisoner may be placed are defined as:
Category A: Those whose escape would be highly dangerous to the public or national security.
Category B: Prisoners for whom the very highest conditions of security are not necessary but for who escape must be made very difficult.
Category C: Prisoners who cannot be trusted in open conditions but who do not have the resources or the will to make a determined escape attempt.
Category D: Prisoners who can reasonably be trusted in open conditions.
Equality and Diversity

All prisoners attending the Trust will be treated with dignity and respect. At the same time it is essential to ensure that both the prisoner and staff members caring for them are kept safe at all times. This may require putting in place special measures for prisoners who are considered by the Prison Service to be at risk of escaping from the premises.
Confidentiality
Absolute patient confidentiality will be maintained at all times and without exception by all Trust Staff involved with the treatment of the prisoner during and following their visit to the Trust.
Detained prisoners must have access to the same standards of care as the wider community. This includes respect for the patient's dignity and privacy.

Prisoners and their families are not permitted to have prior notification of hospital appointments or inpatient stays. This is to minimise the risk of disruption or escape when attending hospital. The only exception to this rule may be for prisoners when special instructions are given (e.g. fasting or specimens are required.) In these cases Prison Healthcare Staff will assess the prisoner's circumstances and will advise them of their appointment as required.
As a rule appointments / inpatient stay notifications should be sent directly to the Healthcare Department at the relevant prison.

There is the intension to agree appointments / admissions over the telephone, rather than receiving a date by letter, to enable other commitments / factors to be taken into account when agreeing these dates and times.

Should an appointment for a prisoner accidentally be sent to their home address, or an address other than the Prison, a new appointment must be booked and the Prison only advised of the new date and time.
Where a follow up appointment is booked at the time when the prisoner is attending the hospital the HM Prison Service Staff, not the prisoner, should be handed the appointment card in an envelope.

No information regarding the presence of a prisoner at the Trust must be communicated and any requests for information, in person or over the phone, should be directed to the HM Prison Service Staff/ Police staff.

The LSMS/ SMD should be made aware of the reason for a person's detainment if it presents a risk to staff or other service users. At no time will the reason for the prisoner's detainment in prison be divulged to Trust staff unless done so by the prisoner themselves.

In the event of a particularly high profile prisoner attending the Trust a pseudonym (fake name) should be considered attached to PAS / clinical systems to prevent unauthorized individuals spuriously observing information about the prisoner. This will require a request to the Data Quality Team. Where possible they should be informed in advance and always be informed at the point of the prisoners discharge date so the team can revert records back to the genuine name. The ward staff will need to know in advance what the pseudonym but the prisoner will not be told.
Infection Prevention and Control
The service will be delivered in accordance and compliance with the Trusts Infection Prevention and Control policies.
Audit and Compliance with Policy
This policy will be audited by the LSMS on an annual basis. An audit tool will be developed in line with the chosen areas of the policy being audited.
Incidents relating to persons under arrest or prisoners will be reviewed to ensure compliance with the agreed policy.
Regular reports on incidents and the outcomes of audits will be sent to the Health and Safety Group as appropriate.
Review
This policy will be reviewed 2 years from the approval date or when required based on legislative or operational protocol changes.
Changes will be made through agreement of all parties' involved
Communication

The policy will be made available on the Trust's intranet. The LSMS will be responsible for issuing copies to all senior managers, service leads and ward sisters for dissemination within their departments.
The approved policy will be notified in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via e-mail to all staff.
This Policy will be issued to Essex Police and HM Prison Service.
References
Health and Safety Executive: Health & Safety at Work Act 1974 Section 4
Health and Safety Executive: The Management of Health & Safety at Work Regulations 1999 regulation 3
The Prison Act 1952 Section 22(2) (b)
The Medical Ethics Department of the British Medical Association guidance.
